I've been able to prove that every localic morphism in Topos\mathrm{Topos}Topos is representably faithful, but I haven't been able to either prove the converse or find a counterexample as yet. My strategy so far has been to prove epicness of the top arrow in the pullback square

P→B↓↓f∗f∗B~→ϵB~B~\begin{CD} P @>>> B\\ @VVV @VVV\\ f^{*}f_{*}\tilde{B} @>{\epsilon_{\tilde{B}}}>> \tilde{B} \end{CD}P↓⏐​f∗f∗​B~​​ϵB~​​​B↓⏐​B~​

However, I've been unable to find geometric transformations lying around that can probe the arbitrary BBB, never mind relating that back to the arrow from PPP. The Elephant in A4.6.2(b) claims that ϵ\epsilonϵ being epic is strictly stronger than fff being localic, so I can't hope to prove that; maybe I can prove that it's epic specifically on partial map classifiers though? Anyone have any ideas?

What does "representably faithful" mean?

My first guess was: a geometric morphism X→YX \to YX→Y is representably faithful if Geom(A,X)→Geom(A,Y)Geom(A, X) \to Geom(A,Y)Geom(A,X)→Geom(A,Y) is faithful for every topos AAA, where Geom(A,Z)Geom(A,Z)Geom(A,Z) is the category of geometric morphisms from A→ZA \to ZA→Z, where a morphism is a natural transformation between the left adjoints. But then if XXX is a localic topos, and Y=SetY = SetY=Set is sheaves on a point, then taking A=SetA = SetA=Set as well, we see that for the localic morphism Y→XY \to XY→X to be representably faithful, the specialization order on YYY must be codiscrete. So for lots of YYY this fails.

My next guess was: a geometric morphism X→YX \to YX→Y is representably faithful if Geom(Y,A)→Geom(X,A)Geom(Y,A) \to Geom(X,A)Geom(Y,A)→Geom(X,A) is faithful for every topos AAA. Now taking A=Fun(FinSet,Set)A = Fun(FinSet, Set)A=Fun(FinSet,Set) to be the object classifier, we see this condition implies that the left adjoint to X→YX \to YX→Y must be faithful. Now, a left or right exact functor between complete / cocomplete categories is faithful if and only if it is conservative, so we see that the left adjoint to X→YX \to YX→Y must be conservative, i.e. X→YX \to YX→Y must be a surjective geometric morphism. So if X→YX \to YX→Y is a geometric morphism between localic toposes which is not surjective, it is not representably faithful in this sense.

Do you know whether every representably fully faithful morphism is an inclusion?

If this is the case, then we can maybe prove that representably faithful implies localic as follows.
Take a geometric morphism f:F→Ef : \mathcal{F} \to \mathcal{E}f:F→E. To show that fff is localic, it is enough to show that the diagonal Δf:F→F×EF\Delta_f : \mathcal{F} \to \mathcal{F}\times_{\mathcal{E}} \mathcal{F}Δf​:F→F×E​F is an inclusion (Elephant C2.4.14). We already know that Δf\Delta_fΔf​ is localic (Elephant B3.3.8(i)), in particular representably faithful. It remains to show that Δf\Delta_fΔf​ is representably full. However, by writing out the definitions, we see that Δf\Delta_fΔf​ is representably full if and only if fff is representably faithful.
(I'm assuming Topos\mathrm{Topos}Topos is the category of Grothendieck toposes and geometric morphisms between them, for elementary toposes we should be careful about boundedness assumptions.)

Johnstone gives a possible counterexample in the Elephant: the geometric morphism f:Sets/X→Sh(X)f : \mathbf{Sets}/X \to \mathbf{Sh}(X)f:Sets/X→Sh(X) for any non-discrete topological space XXX. In this case, fff is not an inclusion, but maybe it is representably fully faithful.

Well, I do know that every inclusion (geometric embedding) is representably fully faithful, but I don't know the converse of that one either, I hadn't paid much attention to it since representably fully faithful is not the 'best' definition of fully faithful morphism in a lot of circumstances (e.g. enriched categories).

I think this mainly comes down to whether there are 'enough' geometric morphisms into a generic topos to show that a representably fully faithful geometric morphism has a fully faithful direct image.
One shouldn't expect every rep. ff geometric morphism to be a geometric inclusion, for the same reason not every monomorphism of topological spaces is a subspace inclusion.

It seems like this intuition leads to the same kind of counterexample for rep. ff -> geometric inclusion as was mentioned above: the surjection from the discrete topos on XXX's set of points to the sheaf topos on XXX itself, for a topological space XXX.

To turn this into a counterexample to rep. faithful -> localic, I'd guess would require an example of a (non-localic!) topos where the induced topology on the diagonal is coarser than the topology on the topos itself.
But this topos would still need to be 'thin' enough that the diagonal is representably ff.

James Deikun said:

It seems like this intuition leads to the same kind of counterexample for rep. ff -> geometric inclusion as was mentioned above: the surjection from the discrete topos on XXX's set of points to the sheaf topos on XXX itself, for a topological space XXX.

I'm having a bit of a hard time convincing myself that this is representably full tbh ...
I don't think it is.

The functor f:Set2→Set→f: Set^{2} \to Set^{\to}f:Set2→Set→ of this type is given by: inverse image forgets the arrow, direct image is (A0,A1)↦(A0×A1,A1,π1)(A_{0}, A_{1}) \mapsto (A_{0} \times A_{1}, A_{1}, \pi_{1})(A0​,A1​)↦(A0​×A1​,A1​,π1​). Maybe in this case we can at least find a counterexample to the supposed counterexample?

Anyone know what Set2\mathrm{Set}^{2}Set2 classifies? Set→\mathrm{Set}^{\to}Set→ classifies subterminal objects but it's on the wrong end of this geometric morphism for that to be especially useful here.
If I read Elephant B3.2.4(a) correctly, Set^2 classifies morphisms 1→1+11 \to 1 + 11→1+1.
That means the above functor associates a subterminal object -- the preimage of one of the 111 s, say the leftmost -- with each such morphism.

So already in the case of Set-valued points, in one case we get a discrete category with two objects and in the other case we get two objects related by a morphism, right? That's not a fully faithful functor.

I think this doesn't completely dispose of the proposed counterexample, though, because the arrow that shows up corresponds to the fact that the Sierpinski space has a nontrivial specialization order. I think this means that finite topological spaces are kinda out as counterexamples though.
Next simplest example of this I can think of: f:Set/∣X∣→Sh(X)f : \mathrm{Set}/|X| \to \mathrm{Sh}(X)f:Set/∣X∣→Sh(X) where XXX is the one-point compactification of the countable discrete space.

I was thinking more in the direction of X=[0,1]X = [0,1]X=[0,1] (the unit interval). Then XXX is Hausdorff as a locale, so it follows that
Geom(E,Sh(X))\mathbf{Geom}(\mathcal{E},\mathbf{Sh}(X))Geom(E,Sh(X)) is a groupoid for each Grothendieck topos E\mathcal{E}E (Elephant C3.6.9(b), C1.2.17(iii)). Points of localic toposes have no nontrivial automorphisms, so essentially Geom(E,Sh(X))\mathbf{Geom}(\mathcal{E},\mathbf{Sh}(X))Geom(E,Sh(X)) is just a set for each E\mathcal{E}E. The same holds for Geom(E,Sets/X)\mathbf{Geom}(\mathcal{E},\mathbf{Sets}/X)Geom(E,Sets/X).

So to show that Geom(E,Sets/X)→Geom(E,Sh(X))\mathbf{Geom}(\mathcal{E},\mathbf{Sets}/X) \to \mathbf{Geom}(\mathcal{E},\mathbf{Sh}(X))Geom(E,Sets/X)→Geom(E,Sh(X)) is an equivalence, it remains to show that two maps E→Sets/X\mathcal{E} \to \mathbf{Sets}/XE→Sets/X that define isomorphic maps E→Sh(X)\mathcal{E} \to \mathbf{Sh}(X)E→Sh(X) are already isomorphic. I believe this is the case, but I'm a bit surprised about how difficult it is to write out a precise proof of this.

I think a possible proof would go like this: we can reduce to the case that E\mathcal{E}E is localic, using the hyperconnected–localic factorization. Then we show that the inclusion O([0,1])→P([0,1])\mathcal{O}([0,1]) \to \mathcal{P}([0,1])O([0,1])→P([0,1]) is an epimorphism in the category of frames. Here O([0,1])\mathcal{O}([0,1])O([0,1]) is the frame of open subsets of [0,1][0,1][0,1] and P([0,1])\mathcal{P}([0,1])P([0,1]) is the frame of all subsets of [0,1][0,1][0,1], or in other words the frame of open subsets for the discrete topology.

So this should give an example of a representably fully faithful morphism that is not an inclusion. I hoped it would bring us closer to the construction of a representably faithful morphism that is not localic, but I don't see at the moment what the next step would be.
It seems like this argument should work for any Hausdorff topological space.
(and show something interesting whenever the space is not discrete)
Maybe it would help to prove something like 'grouplike localic geometric morphisms are representably f.f.' ... assuming that is true.
Then what would remain would be to find a topos whose diagonal is grouplike.
(but not an embedding)

James Deikun said:

Maybe it would help to prove something like 'grouplike localic geometric morphisms are representably f.f.' ... assuming that is true.

I think it isn't true, since Set2\mathrm{Set}^{2}Set2 is a grouplike localic Set\mathrm{Set}Set-topos but its global sections geometric morphism is not representably fully faithful.

James Deikun said:

It seems like this argument should work for any Hausdorff topological space.

Yes, but the topological spaces should be Hausdorff as locale, which is different from Hausdorffness as topological space. In both cases, XXX is Hausdorff if and only if the diagonal X→X×XX \to X \times XX→X×X is closed, but products are computed differently in the category of locales and the category of topological spaces. The two notions agree if XXX is locally compact and sober, or if XXX is completely metrizable, see Picado and A. Pultr, Notes on the products of locales, Proposition 4.4.1 here. I played it a bit too safe by taking [0,1][0,1][0,1], for example the real line would work as well.

The fact that if f is localic, then pt(f) is faithful appears as 4.4 in General facts on the Scott adjunction and I do not expect the inverse implication to be true. May I ask for what motivates your question?

The motivation is the considerable analogies between faithful functors in Cat\mathrm{Cat}Cat and localic geometric morphisms, e.g.:

  • their stability properties
  • their place as the right class of an important factorization
  • their place in a "tower" of conditions on 1-morphisms and their diagonals (Elephant C2.4.14)
  • being a property that indicates relative 'thinness' of the preimage
  • one actually being taken to the other by the Psh\mathrm{Psh}Psh 2-functor

This all made me wonder if localic morphisms can be expressed as a kind of faithful morphism (like, for example, embeddings of topological spaces are 'a kind' of monomorphism) and if so what kind of extra condition, if any, is needed.

Also I certainly don't expect faithfulness on Set\mathrm{Set}Set-valued points alone to detect if a morphism is localic, but I thought faithfulness on all of the Hom\mathrm{Hom}Hom-categories going in just might be enough... I now think it's not enough but I'm still not 100% sure, and I still want to see what a "not quite localic" morphism would actually look like.
